Salmonella Typhi has a moderate infectious dose requirement (10² to 10⁵ bacilli), which contributes to its efficiency as a pathogen and explains why typhoid fever can spread relatively easily through contaminated water and food supplies.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

  • Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. 
  • It is well known to cause gastrointestinal side effects, including diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, particularly when first starting the medication or when the dose is increased. 
  • Diarrhea is one of the most common side effects of metformin and can sometimes be severe or persistent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not commonly associated with diarrhea. Its common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analog used as an adjunct treatment for diabetes. It slows gastric emptying and promotes satiety but is not typically associated with diarrhea. Nausea is a more common gastrointestinal side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is not known to cause diarrhea. Hypoglycemia is its most significant side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, metformin is the anti-diabetic drug most commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea. The patient's symptoms are likely related to metformin use.

questions.text: A patient was started on antihypertensive drugs. Few days later, the patient presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

 

The given picture is suggestive of angioedema. The antihypertensive drug that can lead to the development of angioedema is ACE-Inhibitors – Lisinopril in the given option. Angioedema caused by ACE inhibitors is a class effect, and patients who experience this side effect should not be given any other ACE inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. It can cause side effects such as headache, flushing, and peripheral edema, but it is not typically associated with angioedema.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker used to treat hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions. Its common side effects include bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities, but it does not cause angioedema.

 

Option D. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It can cause side effects such as dry mouth, sedation, and rebound hypertension upon abrupt withdrawal, but it is not associated with angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:-

 

  • Angioedema
  • Cough
  • Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are related to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are specifically used in the staging and prognostication of maxillary sinus carcinoma. Ohngren's line is an imaginary plane drawn from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. This line divides the maxillary sinus into anteroinferior and posterosuperior portions, which has significant prognostic implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebellopontine angle tumor: These tumors are classified using different systems related to their location in the posterior cranial fossa. Ohngren's line has no relevance to cerebellopontine angle tumors, which include acoustic neuromas and meningiomas.

 

Option C. Glomus Jugulare Tumor: These tumors are classified based on their extension from the jugular foramen and involvement of surrounding structures. The Fisch classification system is typically used, not Ohngren's classification.

 

Option D. Basal Cell Carcinoma of eyelid: These tumors are classified according to their histopathological features and TNM staging. Ohngren's line is not used in the classification or prognostication of basal cell carcinomas.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ohngren's line is a critical prognostic indicator in maxillary sinus carcinoma; tumors situated posterosuperior to this line (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those anteroinferior to it (infrastructural) due to their proximity to vital structures.

questions.text: An individual is in an environment of a temperature of 47°C. What is the mechanism of heat loss? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sweating

 

The mechanism of heat loss in the given case is sweating.

 

As long as skin temperature is greater than the temperature of the surroundings, heat can be lost by radiation and conduction. But when the temperature of the surroundings becomes greater than that of the skin, instead of losing heat, the body gains heat by both radiation and conduction. Under these conditions, the only means by which the body can rid itself of heat is by evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiation and B. Conduction are effective when the ambient temperature is lower than the body's skin temperature. However, at temperatures higher than the skin temperature, these methods can result in heat gain rather than heat loss.

 

Option C. Convection can aid in heat loss if the air movement can cool the skin, but at high environmental temperatures, its effectiveness is limited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At high environmental temperatures, the body relies primarily on sweating and evaporation to lose heat and regulate body temperature effectively.

questions.text: Which condition is characterized by flaccid bullae with mucosal involvement and intraepidermal acantholysis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus Vulgaris

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an immunobullous disorder characterized by flaccid bullae that rapidly rupture to form painful erosions with slow healing. 

 

 

  • It shows a suprabasal intraepidermal split with acantholysis (separation of viable epidermal cells from each other) due to IgG autoantibodies against desmoglein-3 and desmoglein-1. 
  • Mucosal involvement is universal (95% of cases), with oral mucosa most frequently affected, presenting as painful erosions. 

 

 

  • The Nikolsky sign is positive due to acantholysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus Foliaceus: 

 

  • Though it's also an intraepidermal immunobullous disorder, it shows subcorneal split (more superficial than PV) with acantholysis due to antibodies against only desmoglein-1. Importantly, mucosal lesions are absent, and it primarily affects seborrheic areas (chest, scalp). 
  • Bullae are transient and superficial, usually manifesting as scaling and crusting.

 

 

Option C. Pemphigus Erythematosus: 

 

  • This is a less severe variant of pemphigus foliaceus characterized by dry, hyperkeratotic, scaly lesions, particularly affecting the malar region of the face. 

 

 

  • Like pemphigus foliaceus, mucosal involvement is absent.

 

Option D. Bullous Pemphigoid: 

 

  • Unlike pemphigus, bullous pemphigoid shows a subepidermal split (not intraepidermal) with tense rather than flaccid bullae. 

 

 

  • It targets basement membrane proteins (BPAG 1 and 2), not desmosomal proteins. 
  • Mucosal involvement occurs in only 10-30% of cases, and there's no acantholysis. 
  • The Nikolsky sign is negative.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is uniquely characterized by the triad of flaccid bullae, universal mucosal involvement, and suprabasal acantholysis due to anti-desmoglein 3 antibodies, distinguishing it from other vesiculobullous disorders.
